'Mokum' (××§××) is the Yiddish word for "place" or "safe
haven". [http://www.yiddishdictionaryonline.com/dictionary/m Yiddish
Dictionary Online] It is similar to the Hebrew word makom (××§××, "place"),
from which it is derived. [http://www.milon.co.il/general/general.php?term=-
%D7%9E%D7%A7%D7%95%D7%9D Milon] In Yiddish the names of some cities in the
Netherlands and Germany were shortened to Mokum and had the first letter of the
name of the city, transliterated into the Hebrew alphabet, added to them. Cities
named this way were Amsterdam, Berlin, Delft, and Rotterdam. {{cite web
  | last = Martens first = Hadewych title = Jiddisch, ontstaan en etymologie
  | work = [http://www.ety.nl/ www.ety.nl] date = 2006-09-26 url =
  | http://www.ety.nl/jiddisch.html accessdate = 2007-08-11 }}

Mokum, without [[Aleph]], is still used as a nickname for Amsterdam. The
nickname was first considered to be Bargoens, a form of Dutch slang, but in the
20th century it lost its negative sound and is now used as a nickname for
Amsterdam in a sentimental context. {{cite book
  | last = Berns first = Jan coauthors = Daan, Jo title = Hij zeit wat. De
  | Amsterdamse volkstaal publisher = BZZTÃ´H year = 1992 location = The Hague
  | language = Dutch isbn = 90-629-756-9 page = 66
}}
